You certainly raise a valid point here. Somehow, I think the difference between Weiner and Bill Clinton is the former's skimpier political record and lack of charisma.  By the time he reached presidency, Clinton was an accomplished politician with nation-wide recognition for what he has achieved and not for how many women he cheated on his wife with.

All this sex, so confusing, isn't it?  But I think for many  people, sex aside, the issue with Wiener running for mayor, is an issue of judgement. The big push, particularly with that piece in the NYT Mag, about his recovery and working on his marriage, while he knew that this second bombshell would come out! It is reckless and that is what scares me about having him in office.

Yes, we like to get all morally uptight for a bit.  However I think that while it may not be articulated well, this risky conduct raises questions about the perpetrator's judgment.  In Clinton's case, we knew he was a skilled and capable President when his scandal broke.  Weiner has a thin political resume and seems to be taking greater risks (Internet!) for less reward (no physical contact) and of more concern seems unable to control himself emotionally in several ways.  He is very untested regarding his political / personal talents.

In light of the overwhelmingly negative comments about Weiner here, it's interesting to recall that Bill Clinton was a well-known serial cheater who reverted to this bad behavior at least once while holding the highest office in the land. I agree that this latest bombshell about Weiner makes it hard to take him seriously as a candidate. But is sending out naughty texts to young women and lying about it worse than actually engaging in oral sex with a young woman in the Oval Office and lying about it? Clinton now is widely regarded as a good president, but everyone here is talking about Weiner like he's worse than garbage. It seems like there's a big double standard going on here.

And don't get me wrong, I'm a loyal Democrat, but I still find all this very disappointing.

Yep, a friend of mine clicked without thinking on a malware link - he is a security expert, the body of the email was nothing like my normal communications - and the only thing that saved him was a corporate security system that pointed out that it was a known bad site.

Just keep deleting those attachments unread...

Emails like those often contain exploits and drop malware onto your system. And no, AV does not stop them even 1% of the time. AV and internet security suites expect traditional malware to be delivered via email and exploits via malicious URLs or infected websites. The techology to detect exploits embedded in emails does not exist today.

As an example, two of the most secure companies in the world, RSA and Lockheed Martin, were compromised by via emails containing documents (or spreadsheets) with embedded exploits.

Bottom line: don't open email attachments unless you know the sender. And if they look strange, not even then.

Small correction -- in my experience (as a lawyer who lived through all of this), it's incorrect to say that "the long investor is typically called the 'transaction sponsor.'"  Typically, synthetic CDOs had multiple long investors.  The "sponsor" usually refers to the investor that expresses interest upfront in buying the "equity" (or "first-loss") tranche of the CDO.  The equity was often the hardest tranche to find a buyer for, so an underwriter often wouldn't go forward with a synthetic CDO (or a regular cash CDO, for that matter) without a "sponsor" who was indicating interest.  The fact issue between the SEC and the defense here is whether "sponsor" on its own is enough to communicate "long" or "long only."
